Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of comments:

  • General sentiment: Strong dissatisfaction with the current tipping culture. Many feel it’s overextended, coercive, and shifts labor costs from employers to customers.
  • Core principle most agree on: Tipping should be voluntary, tied to the quality of service, and not expected for minimal or no service.
  • Who should be tipped: Broad support for tipping in full-service restaurants and for delivery drivers; frequent pushback against tipping for counter service, pickup orders, coffee shops, and simple transactions.
  • Pay and policy changes favored:
  • Require employers to pay a living wage (at least full minimum wage for tipped workers) so income doesn’t hinge on tips.
  • Reduce or remove tipping prompts, especially pre-service prompts and intrusive tablet screens; add an easy “no tip” option; only prompt where real service is provided.
  • Replace tipping with built-in service charges or higher menu prices so workers are paid fairly without relying on tips. Some suggest modest service fees (around 10%) with optional additional tips.
  • Views on keeping tipping: A minority strongly supports tipping as an incentive for great service and regularly tips generously; a smaller subset endorses higher standard rates (e.g., 20–30%) or even mandatory tipping unless wages meet a specific floor.
  • Concerns raised:
  • Social pressure and “guilt tipping,” especially via POS tablets.
  • Unpredictable income for workers and confusion for customers about when/how much to tip.
  • Expansion of tipping requests to contexts that don’t involve meaningful service.
  • Less common or mixed ideas:
  • Make tipping fixed amounts rather than percentages for small bills.
  • Exempt tips from taxation or have employers match a portion of tips.
  • Provide small rewards for tipping (thank-you notes, coupons).
  • Establish clearer standards for who is tipped and when.

Bottom line: Most want to curb tip creep, ensure workers earn a stable, livable wage from employers, and reserve tipping as a discretionary bonus for clear, high-quality service—often limited to traditional, full-service contexts.

Summary B

Based on the comments provided, here is an overall summary of the perspectives on tipping:

There is a strong and widespread dissatisfaction with the current state of tipping culture, with many describing it as "out of control," "forced," and "a scam." A significant percentage of commentators believe the fundamental problem is that tipping allows employers to underpay their staff, shifting the responsibility of providing a livable wage onto the customer. The most frequently proposed solution is to eliminate the tipping system entirely and require businesses to pay their employees a fair, livable wage, similar to models used in Europe and other parts of the world.

Many express frustration with "tipping creep," where requests for tips have expanded beyond traditional sit-down restaurant service to counter service, pickup orders, and nearly every point-of-sale transaction, often facilitated by tablet payment systems. This has created a sense of pressure and obligation, making it uncomfortable for customers to decline a tip even when little to no service was provided.

While the desire to abolish the system is a dominant theme, there is also a strong belief that if tipping is to exist, it should return to its original purpose: a voluntary and optional reward for exceptional service, not an expected subsidy for wages. Some suggest alternative systems, such as a mandatory service charge included in the bill, to create more predictability for both workers and customers.

A smaller portion of comments express support for tipping, viewing it as a necessary way to support underpaid workers, a good deed, or an effective incentive for employees to provide excellent service. However, even among those who currently tip generously, many do so out of a sense of obligation due to the low wages of service workers, while still wishing the system itself would change.
